src:
Security forces kill protester in Iraq, wound dozens
02 Nov 2019, 18:03 by QASSIM ABDUL-ZAHRA, Associated Press



Anti-government protesters rest during ongoing protests in Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. (AP Photo/Hadi Mizban)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.



Iraqi artists drawing graffiti near Tahrir Square during anti-government ongoing protests in Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. (AP Photo/Hadi Mizban)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.



Anti-government protesters stand on barriers set by Iraqi security forces to close the Joumhouriya bridge leading to the Green Zone government areas during ongoing protests in Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. (AP Photo/Hadi Mizban)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.



Volunteers prepare free food to anti-government protesters during ongoing protests in Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. (AP Photo/Hadi Mizban)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.



Volunteers prepare free food to anti-government protesters during ongoing protests in Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. (AP Photo/Hadi Mizban)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.



Anti-government protesters stand near graffiti messages in Arabic, including "Iraqi women, said no to the Tyrants," and "I will not waste you," near Tahrir Square during ongoing protests in Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. (AP Photo/Hadi Mizban)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.



Funeral of a killed protester, Abbas Qassim, 17, passes through Tahrir Square, Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. Qassim was killed during anti-government ongoing protests, his family said. (AP Photo/Hadi Mizban)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.



Anti-government protesters gather in Tahrir Square during ongoing protests in Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. The Arabic sentence writing on the asphalt reads "Parliament is corrupt." (AP Photo/Hadi Mizban)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.



Funeral of a killed protester, Abbas Qassim, 17, passes through Tahrir Square, Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. Qassim was killed during anti-government ongoing protests, his family said. (AP Photo/Hadi Mizban)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.



Anti-government protesters gather in Tahrir Square during ongoing protests in Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. (AP Photo/Khalid Mohammed)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.



Anti-government protesters take control of the first barriers set by Iraqi security forces to close the Joumhouriya bridge leading to the Green Zone and gather on the bank of the Tigris during ongoing protests in Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. (AP Photo/Khalid Mohammed)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.



Anti-government protesters, right, take control of the first barriers set by Iraqi security forces, left, to close the Joumhouriya bridge leading to the Green Zone government areas during ongoing protests in Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. (AP Photo/Khalid Mohammed)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.



Volunteers distribute free food to anti-government protesters during ongoing protests in Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. (AP Photo/Khalid Mohammed)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.



Anti-government protesters take control of the first barriers set by Iraqi security forces to close the Joumhouriya bridge leading to the Green Zone during ongoing protests in Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. (AP Photo/Khalid Mohammed)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.



Anti-government protesters gather in Tahrir Square during ongoing protests in Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. (AP Photo/Khalid Mohammed)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.



Volunteers distribute free food to anti-government protesters and security forces during ongoing protests in Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. (AP Photo/Khalid Mohammed)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.



Anti-government protesters gather in Tahrir Square during ongoing protests in Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. Tahrir Square, Baghdad's biggest and most central plaza on the eastern banks of the Tigris, has become the epicenter. Thousands have been camped out in the circle with its famous Freedom Monument and palm trees in the middle. (AP Photo/Khalid Mohammed)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.



Anti-government protesters take control of the first barriers set by Iraqi security forces to close the Joumhouriya bridge leading to the Green Zone and gather on the bank of the Tigris river during ongoing protests in Baghdad, Iraq, Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. (AP Photo/Khalid Mohammed)Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.


BAGHDADÂ (AP) - Iraqi security forces fired tear gas and live ammunition to disperse thousands of anti-government protesters Saturday, killing at least one and wounding more than 200 in the capital Baghdad and in the country's south, police officials and a semi-official human rights commission said.
The largest protest took place in Baghdad, where tens of thousands of people gathered in and near a central square in defiance of a government crackdown that killed dozens over the past month.
Tens of thousands of Iraqis have been protesting, mostly in Baghdad and southern regions, since last month, demanding sweeping change to the political system established after the 2003 U.S.-led invasion, which they blame for widespread corruption, high unemployment and poor public services.
Iraq's Foreign Ministry called on countries that issued statements urging Iraq's government to respect the will of Iraqis, saying those states "should respect Iraq's sovereignty and not interfere in Iraq's internal affairs."
In the southern town of Umm Qasr, clashes between security forces and protesters injured 120 people, according to Iraq's semi-official human rights commission.
The Iraqi High Commission For Human Rights said security forces fired tear gas and live bullets to disperse hundreds of protesters near the vital Umm Qasr port on the Persian Gulf on Saturday morning. The commission said many of the wounded were being treated in a hospital in the town.
In Baghdad, security forces fired tear gas at protesters who tried to cross to bridges over the Tigris River leading to the heavily fortified Green Zone that is home to the Iraqi government and several other embassies, including the U.S. mission.
One protester was killed and at least 88 were wounded in Baghdad, according to police and medical officials who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak to the media.
"Down with the government, down with the regime and down with corrupt parties," some of the protesters chanted in Baghdad.
On nearby Abu Nawas Street on the Tigris, protesters prevented authorities from closing it with a blast wall by confiscating the crane that was to be used to place the giant cement blocks.
Authorities had closed nearby Saadoun Street with blocks last month as it is a main road leading to Tahrir Square that has been the main protesting point in the capital since last month.
The weekslong protests in Iraq and similar demonstrations in Lebanon have been fueled by local grievances and mainly directed at the political elite, but they also pose a challenge to Iran, which closely backs both governments. An increasingly violent crackdown in Iraq has raised fears of a backlash by Iran and its heavily armed local allies.
Copyright 2019 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.
